user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. In this fragment pool->memory is being freed (ownership transferred to free/munmap/VirtualFree), so it must be a modifiable pointer type (free takes void *). Rule 8.13 recommends adding const where possible, but not when the pointer denotes owned, deallocatable memory. A hypothetical violation would be if struct MemoryPool declared memory as a non-const pointer but the pointed-to object is never modified anywhere — e.g. it should be declared const char *memory — however that would be incompatible with calling free without a cast. Given only the shown code, there is no evidence of a Rule 8.13 violation.
